Europe.description: European Space Agency member states and EU

Western-aligned.description: Global excluding Russia and China (~65% of mass, ~69% of launches)

massData.sourceNotes: Mass data estimated from: BryceTech Briefings (2020-2024), Space Foundation Reports, Jonathan McDowell's Space Statistics (planet4589.org), ESA Annual Reports. 2024 confirmed at ~1,900 tonnes total (+40% YoY). 2022 confirmed at ~1,000 tonnes (Bryce). Historical and forecast values interpolated/extrapolated. Starlink accounts for ~70-80% of LEO constellation mass.
massData.methodology: Total mass to orbit by segment. User can apply their own $/kg assumptions to derive revenue estimates. Default $/kg values provided but adjustable.

LEO constellations.notes: Dominated by Starlink (~80% of mass). Includes OneWeb, Kuiper (from 2025), Chinese constellations (GuoWang, Qianfan). Starlink V2 Mini at ~800kg vs V1 at ~260kg drives mass growth faster than satellite count.

Government civil.notes: NASA science missions, ESA programs (Copernicus, exploration), JAXA, ISRO institutional. Relatively stable growth. Includes Earth observation, planetary science, space telescopes.

Defense / national security.notes: US Space Force, NRO, SDA proliferated constellations, China/Russia military. Fastest growing segment due to proliferated LEO architectures. SDA Tranche contracts driving rapid expansion.

GEO comsat.notes: Traditional large GEO communication satellites. Declining as LEO constellations capture market share. Typical GEO comsat 4-7 tonnes. 8-12 launches annually declining to 4-6.

Human spaceflight.notes: ISS resupply (Dragon, Cygnus, Progress), crew rotation, China space station. Growing with commercial stations (Axiom, Orbital Reef). Dragon cargo ~6t, crew capsules 12-15t.

Lunar / cislunar.notes: Artemis SLS (~27t to TLI), CLPS lunar landers, China Chang'e, Gateway logistics. Starship HLS will significantly increase mass once operational. Fastest growth trajectory.

Other (rideshare, demos).notes: Transporter rideshare missions, technology demonstrations, university CubeSats, emerging nation first satellites. Small launcher proliferation driving growth.

LEO constellations.notes: OneWeb (Eutelsat-OneWeb), IRIS² constellation deployment starting 2027. Limited European LEO presence until IRIS² ramps up. Ariane 6 as primary launch vehicle.

Government civil.notes: ESA science missions, Copernicus Sentinel series, national programs. Ariane 6 and Vega C as primary vehicles. Stable institutional demand.

Defense / national security.notes: France (SYRACUSE, CSO), UK (Skynet), Germany (SARah). Growing with EU defense initiatives and IRIS² government component.

GEO comsat.notes: EUTELSAT, SES traditional GEO business. Ariane historically dominant in GEO market but declining with global trend. Gap during Ariane 5 to 6 transition.

Human spaceflight.notes: No independent European crewed capability. European Service Module for Orion. Future contributions via Artemis partnership. ATV retired 2015.

Lunar / cislunar.notes: ESA lunar missions via Artemis partnership, European contributions to Gateway (I-Hab, ESPRIT). HERA asteroid mission. Growing European lunar ambition.

Other (rideshare, demos).notes: Vega C rideshare, emerging European small launchers (Isar Aerospace, RFA, PLD Space). University CubeSats. Growing from near-zero.

launchData.sourceNotes: Launch counts from Space Stats Online (definitive source), FAA/AST reports, ESA Annual Space Environment Report. 2020: 114, 2021: 145, 2022: 186, 2023: 222, 2024: 259 (actual counts). Forecasts assume growth moderating from ~15% to ~8% annually by 2030.

pricingAssumptions.description: Default $/kg assumptions for deriving revenue. These are configurable by the user. Prices decline over time due to reusability and competition. Values in USD per kg.

LEO constellations.notes: Bulk constellation launches, high reusability. SpaceX Transporter ~$5k/kg for rideshare; dedicated Starlink missions ~$1.5-2k/kg. Starship will drive further reductions.

Government civil.notes: Government missions often require specific orbits, reliability requirements, and domestic providers. Premium pricing but declining with competition.

Defense / national security.notes: Historically highest pricing due to security requirements, dedicated launches, mission assurance. Proliferated LEO driving costs down as volume increases.

GEO comsat.notes: GTO launches require more energy. Heavy satellites (4-7t). Ariane 5 historically $10-15k/kg, Falcon 9 around $6-8k/kg for GTO. Dual-manifest reduces per-sat cost.

Human spaceflight.notes: Highest safety requirements. Commercial Crew contracts ~$55M/seat. Dragon ~$2.6B for 6 missions. Premium but declining with more providers.

Lunar / cislunar.notes: Beyond LEO requires much more delta-v. SLS at ~$150k/kg to TLI. Starship aims for <$10k/kg eventually. CLPS landers at ~$50k/kg currently.

Other (rideshare, demos).notes: Mix of dedicated small launchers (expensive per kg) and rideshare (cheaper). Electron ~$25k/kg, Transporter rideshare ~$5k/kg. Average declining.

orbitConversion.description: LEO-equivalent conversion factors based on delta-v requirements. Validated by real launcher data: Falcon Heavy (2.4:1 LEO:GTO), Delta IV Heavy (2:1). User can adjust to model their specific launcher.

Human spaceflight.notes: ISS, Tiangong, future stations all LEO

Lunar / cislunar.notes: TLI requires ~3x LEO capacity (delta-v: +3.1 km/s from LEO)

Other (rideshare, demos).notes: Mostly LEO rideshare with occasional GTO secondaries

dataMethodology.massEstimation: Mass data is primary. Revenue is derived by multiplying mass × $/kg. This provides transparency vs opaque revenue figures.

segmentDefinitions.LEO constellations: Commercial and government LEO mega-constellations for communications, EO, IoT. Starlink, OneWeb, Kuiper, IRIS², Chinese constellations.
segmentDefinitions.Government civil: Non-military government missions: science, Earth observation (Copernicus), exploration, space agencies' institutional payloads.
segmentDefinitions.Defense / national security: Military and intelligence satellites including proliferated LEO (SDA), reconnaissance, secure comms, early warning.
segmentDefinitions.GEO comsat: Traditional geostationary communication satellites, broadcast, and high-throughput satellites.
segmentDefinitions.Human spaceflight: Crew and cargo to space stations (ISS, Tiangong, future commercial stations). Includes crew capsules and logistics vehicles.
segmentDefinitions.Lunar / cislunar: Missions beyond LEO: lunar landers, Gateway logistics, deep space probes, cislunar infrastructure.
segmentDefinitions.Other (rideshare, demos): Technology demonstrations, university CubeSats, rideshare aggregators, emerging nation first satellites.

dataMethodology.caveat: Segment boundaries are imperfect. Some missions span categories (e.g., dual-use civil/military). Totals represent best estimates based on available data.
